stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing and debugging a key mechanic in Course 14: a pull-tab to open a large cardboard box leading to a 'hell' area. The stream involved brainstorming design ideas, 3D modeling, animation, and an extensive, deep-dive debugging session to fix a complex, emulator-specific bug inherited from the original SM64 code.

development_findings.summary: A significant performance issue in a level was traced back to an infinite draw distance setting left over from a previous project. Correcting this legacy setting dramatically improved the frame rate.
development_findings.quote: The reason it ran poorly is because back from my other RoMac, I still had the drawing distance for everything set at infinite.

development_findings.summary: A complex, emulator-specific bug was caused by an issue in the original Mario 64 code where two different variables were used interchangeably. Kaze had to debug and fix this vanilla code to make his new mechanic work reliably.
development_findings.quote: It should work by action state not action arc. That's weird how that's done. They really just use action arc and action state interchangeably vanilla.

development_findings.summary: The mechanic for entering a new area evolved from a zipper (rejected) to tape (technically difficult) to a final, implemented idea of a cardboard box pull-tab, inspired by chat.
The game will feature 45 optional bonus missions provided by a Yoshi character, similar to the comet stars in Super Mario Galaxy. These will not be included in the next demo.
The Mario player model has been updated with higher-resolution textures, 3D buttons on his overalls, a jiggling nose, and other small visual enhancements.
Kaze is aiming for a specific 'crafty' aesthetic that looks like layered paper, consciously trying to avoid other established visual styles from different mods.
development_findings.quote: I want it to look like there's paper on paper here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's game design philosophy prioritizes thematic cohesion over showcasing technical novelties. Features must fit the game's world and aesthetic.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to make a Romic exhibiting random technology. That's not what I'm interested in.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes a formal 'hard mode' is unnecessary for this game, as the core mechanics of Mario 64 inherently allow players to create their own difficulty by choosing riskier strategies.
context_findings.quote: You can just decide to play the game without collecting coins. That's the beauty of Mario 64. You may get a hard mode. If you want a hard mode, just play risky.

context_findings.summary: When discussing YouTuber Pannenkoek, Kaze reveals an appreciation for creating content that is comprehensive and timeless, even if he personally prefers a faster-paced presentation style.
context_findings.quote: I think he is thinking about people watching this video 3,000 years down the line. Like, he wants this video to never lose relevance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experimenting with YouTube Shorts but has found the financial return on investment to be poor, and feels they clutter his channel with content resembling mobile ads.
Kaze lives in Canada but is originally from Germany, and expresses a strong negative opinion of his home country.
The stream ended because Kaze's wife, Zeina, had friends visiting, showing a direct intersection of his work schedule and personal life.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested the initial idea of using a zipper to open the cardboard box area, which Kaze later rejected as thematically unfitting.
Kaze referenced a screenshot from Biobak while working on the box model, indicating Biobak provides concept art or visual mockups for game assets.

zeina.summary: Zeina's social plans created a hard stop for the development stream, highlighting the direct influence of their shared personal life on the project's work schedule.

key_stories.title: Designing the Cardboard Box Entrance
key_stories.summary: The entrance to a key level area went through several design iterations. An initial 'zipper' idea was rejected as thematically inappropriate, leading to a collaborative brainstorming process that resulted in a more fitting and clever 'cardboard pull-tab' mechanic.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a thematically appropriate and technically feasible way for the player to open a large cardboard box to access a new 'hell' themed area within a level.
key_stories.process: The initial idea from Biobak was a zipper, which Kaze rejected. Kaze then considered using tape, but worried about the technical complexity of animating it. After brainstorming other ideas like staples and knives, he saw a suggestion for a pull-tab, which he embraced and began implementing.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze, with inspiration from his chat, decided on a pull-tab strip common on real cardboard boxes. He successfully modeled, animated, and implemented this feature, feeling it was a cool and fitting solution.
key_stories.key_quote: A zipper feels so unfitting. Maybe if I Google cardboard box, there's some inspiration here.

key_stories.title: The Cross-Emulator Ghost Bug
key_stories.summary: A frustrating, emulator-specific bug forced Kaze into a deep technical dive. The solution wasn't in his own new code, but required him to find and fix a latent logic flaw in the original Super Mario 64 engine, highlighting the challenges of building on decompiled source code.
key_stories.challenge: A critical bug caused Mario to let go of the pull-tab object unexpectedly, but only on the Project64 emulator, making it extremely difficult to debug.
key_stories.process: Kaze used the Nemu debugger to trace the variable causing the issue. After following a few false leads, he pinpointed the exact line in the vanilla 'holding Bowser' code that was incorrectly overwriting a value. He then modified this base game code to resolve the conflict.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified and fixed the bug by correcting a logic error in the original vanilla Mario 64 code, where two variables were being used interchangeably. This demonstrates the need to not only build new code but also deconstruct and repair the original game's foundation.
key_stories.key_quote: It goes to zero. How does that make any sense? I am so confused by this.
